Chapter 31: Protecting Precepts, Protecting Precepts. This bodhisattva practices all good paths in this way.
In good and bad paths, general characteristics and specific characteristics;
Each is individually known to have two kinds of consequences.
As for the general characteristics of the ten wholesome courses of action,
If one is born in the heavens or among humans.
As for the specific characteristics,
There are two kinds of consequences for the wholesome practice of refraining from killing:
First, long life; second, few illnesses.
There are two kinds of consequences for the wholesome practice of refraining from stealing:
First, great wealth; second, unique possessions.
There are two kinds of consequences for the wholesome practice of refraining from sexual misconduct:
First, a faithful wife; second, not being destroyed by outsiders.
There are two kinds of fruits and rewards for the good conduct of abstaining from false speech:
First, not being slandered or defamed by others; second, not being deceived by others.
There are two kinds of fruits and rewards for the good conduct of abstaining from divisive speech:
First, obtaining good retinue; second, not being destroyed by others.
There are two kinds of fruits and rewards for the good conduct of abstaining from harsh speech:
First, hearing sounds according to one's wishes; second, being free from disputes.
There are two kinds of fruits and rewards for the good conduct of abstaining from frivolous speech:
First, others believing and accepting one's words; second, one's words being decisive.
There are two kinds of fruits and rewards for the good conduct of abstaining from covetousness:
First, contentment; second, few desires.
There are two kinds of fruits and rewards for the good conduct of abstaining from ill-will:
First, always seeking good things for others in one's place of birth; second, not delighting in harming sentient beings.
There are two kinds of fruits and rewards for the good conduct of right view:
First, being free from flattery and deceit, second, having pure views.
The ten unwholesome courses of action are also like this. As for the general characteristics of the results of retribution,
those of superior conduct fall into hell, those of middling conduct fall into the animal realm, and those of inferior conduct fall into the realm of hungry ghosts.
As for the specific characteristics of the results of retribution,
there are two kinds of results of retribution for the unwholesome practice of killing:
first, a short lifespan, second, many illnesses.
There are two kinds of results of retribution for the unwholesome practice of stealing:
first, poverty, second, loss of wealth.
There are two kinds of results of retribution for the unwholesome practice of sexual misconduct:
first, obtaining an ugly wife who is also unchaste, second, being destroyed by others.
There are two kinds of results of retribution for the unwholesome practice of false speech:
first, being slandered by others, second, being deceived by others.
There are two kinds of results of retribution for the unwholesome practice of divisive speech:
First, one obtains evil retinue; second, one's retinue is destructible.
Evil speech and unwholesome conduct have two kinds of karmic retributions:
First, one hears evil sounds with the ears; second, there is always fighting and quarreling.
Scattered speech and unwholesome conduct have two kinds of karmic retributions:
First, one's words are not trusted; second, one's words lack substance.
Greed and unwholesome conduct have two kinds of karmic retributions:
First, the mind is not content; second, one desires much and is insatiable.
Anger and unwholesome conduct have two kinds of karmic retributions:
First, one has an evil nature; second, one delights in harming sentient beings.
Wrong views and unwholesome conduct have two kinds of karmic retributions:
First, one's mind is deceitful; second, one falls into wrong views.
Having understood, one delights in the Dharma, and one's mind is unmoved by the Dharma;
Among all sentient beings, one's compassionate mind becomes even more superior.
Delighting in the Dharma means:
But they love the Dharma, and there is no greater matter than this.
Here, the Dharma refers to the ten wholesome courses of action mentioned earlier.
Delighting in the Dharma means:
They only delight in the Dharma, and there is no other matter.
Their minds are unmoved by the Dharma means:
Even at the cost of their lives, they will never abandon the Dharma.
Bodhisattvas practice such Dharma, and their compassion for sentient beings becomes even greater.

Although there is compassion in the first ground, it is not as great as in this ground, because by penetrating the causes and conditions of virtuous and non-virtuous actions, they feel pity for sentient beings who are all subject to their own actions and lack independence, and thus they have no thoughts of anger, resentment, or hatred.
Practicing in this way, their compassion becomes even greater.
They think:
Alas! All sentient beings deeply fall into wrong views;
I should expound the right view, enabling them to enter the right path.
Bodhisattvas penetrate the causes and conditions of virtuous and non-virtuous actions, and deeply practice compassion for all sentient beings.
They think:
Sentient beings are to be pitied. Because they do not know the true nature of dharmas, they often give rise to false thoughts and various wrong views.
Because of wrong views, they give rise to afflictions;
Because of afflictions, they give rise to various karmas;
Because of the causes and conditions of giving rise to karmas, they transmigrate in birth and death.
I have previously given rise to the resolve to seek supreme perfect enlightenment in order to deliver sentient beings. I shall now expound the correct view.
These sentient beings are those I should deliver. I shall now expound the correct view for them, enabling them to enter the true path and attain liberation.
Having had such thoughts, he knew that sentient beings have various afflictions, namely:ğŸ”½Contemplating the afflictions that arise
And the various defilements of afflictions;ğŸ”½The various black evil karmas
And the various sufferings and afflictions they experience.ğŸ”½Having compassion for sentient beings,
Who lack much;ğŸ”½Having contemplated various things,
They are all like me.
At that time, with a compassionate mind, he expediently made a great vow:
How can I cause sentient beings to extinguish all this suffering?ğŸ”½As for afflictions and afflictive defilements,
those that are included in the latent afflictions are called afflictions, and those that are included in the entanglements are called defilements.
As for afflictions that are included in the latent afflictions,

they are greed, hatred, pride, ignorance, the view of the self, the view of the extremes, the view of grasping rules and rituals, the view of holding one's own view as supreme, and wrong views and doubts.

These ten fundamental [afflictions] are classified as the ninety-eight latent afflictions based on whether they are eliminated through the path of seeing or the path of cultivation in the three realms.
As for those not included in the latent afflictions,

they are lack of faith, shamelessness, lack of conscience, flattery, playfulness, haughtiness, stubbornness, laziness, discouragement, sleepiness, irritability, stinginess, jealousy, arrogance, intolerance, and insatiability.
It is also because of the distinctions between the views and contemplations of the three realms that there are one hundred and ninety-six entanglements and defilements.
Some say:
Afflictions are in the deep mind, while defilements are in the shallow mind.
Some say:
All hindrances and obstructions are called entanglements and defilements, while the rest are all called afflictions.
Black evil karma refers to the seven unwholesome courses of action, as well as the volition associated with greed, ill-will, and wrong views, which can produce painful retributions.
Various kinds of suffering and distress means that various evil things in the body are called suffering, while various evil things in the mind are called distress.
Moreover, suffering in this world is called suffering, while falling into evil destinies in the future is called distress.
Having much that is lacking means that either the faculties and limbs, or the necessities of life, or the various merits such as faith and precepts are incomplete, so it is called lacking.
The remaining phrases are easy to understand, as explained in the verses, and do not need further explanation.
Having contemplated in this way, sentient beings are to be greatly pitied, falling into the two vehicles;
I should make a vow for them, causing them to abide in the Great Vehicle.
This matter is like this. In the DaÅ›abhÅ«mika-sÅ«tra, Vajragarbha Bodhisattva himself said:
This bodhisattva is apart from the ten unwholesome courses of action, and also causes sentient beings to abide in the ten wholesome courses of action.

For the sake of sentient beings, he deeply seeks - with a superior mind, a good mind, a joyful mind, a compassionate mind, a mind of kindness and compassion, a mind of benefit and profit, a mind of protection and guardianship, a mind of ownership, a mind of great teacher, a mind of inclusion and acceptance, and a mind of receiving and taking.
Having thought like this,
These sentient beings are to be greatly pitied, falling into various wrong intentions and wrong views, practicing wrong and dangerous paths;
I should now cause them to abide in the path of true right views.
These sentient beings are of different kinds and compete with each other.
They always harbor anger and resentment, with hatred and vexation raging;
However, I will cause them to abide in the unsurpassed great compassion.
These sentient beings are insatiable, greedily seeking the benefits of others, and sustaining themselves through wrong livelihood;
I will cause them to abide in the pure bodily, verbal, and mental actions.
These sentient beings, within the causes and conditions of desire, anger, and ignorance, constantly give rise to various afflictions and fetters, yet do not seek to liberate themselves;
I will extinguish their various sufferings and afflictions, causing them to abide in a place free from suffering and affliction.
These sentient beings, obscured by ignorance, enter the dense forest of darkness and are unable to extricate themselves;
Departing from the illumination of wisdom, they enter the perilous and evil paths of various views;
I should rescue them, causing them to attain the eye of unobstructed wisdom;
With this wisdom-eye, not following others, they will know the true characteristics of all dharmas.
These sentient beings fall into the long-flowing river of birth and death, wishing to fall into the pits of hell, animals, hungry ghosts, and asuras, entering the net of crookedness.
Covered by various afflictions and evil grasses, without a guide, they do not give rise to the thought of leaving.
They say the path is not the path, and the not-path is the path.
The people of Mara, enemies and thieves always follow them, without a good teacher.
Following the intentions of Mara, they stay far away from the Buddha's teachings.
I should enable these sentient beings to cross over this dangerous and evil path of birth and death and attain the city of fearlessness, decay, and all wisdom.
These sentient beings are carried away by the streams of desire, existence, views, and ignorance, covered by the waves of various evil deeds.

They sink in the river of craving, following the waves of birth and death, turning in the whirlpools unable to escape on their own, their salty water of the perceptions of desire, anger, and irritation rotting them, and they are seized by the rakshasa of the view of self.
Entering the deep forest of the five desires, they are attached to the blowing of joy and defilement, on the land of self-conceit, they are extremely pitiful, without an island, without rescue.
In the empty village of the six sense bases, they are unable to move, without a good guide;
Such beings, I should now use the firm wisdom ship of great compassion to carry them to the island of omniscience, which is peaceful and fearless.
These beings, who are full of suffering and pitiable, are locked up in the prison of birth, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress.

They harbor much greed, hatred, and love, fall into the four inverted views, are harmed by the poisonous snakes of the four elements, are destroyed by the five aggregates' enemies, are trapped by the deceitful thieves of joy and defilement, and experience immeasurable suffering in the empty village of the six sense bases;
I should break their prison of birth and death, enabling them to attain the peace, freedom, and unobstructed nirvana, and experience peace and joy.
These sentient beings are to be greatly pitied. They are narrow-minded, small-minded, and content with little benefit. They lack the mind of omniscience.
Even if they seek to leave [samsara], they delight in the Hearer and Solitary Realizer Vehicles;
I should enable them to attain a great mind and delight in the Buddha's vast teachings.
The bodhisattva who practices in this way will attain the power of upholding precepts,
And skillfully give rise to wholesome actions, enabling them to increase and flourish.
This is the Buddha's disciple who deeply enters the ground of freedom from defilements.

With a pure and one-pointed mind, fully upholding the ten wholesome precepts, one will attain the power of cultivating merit.

From the first ground, they begin to be born, up to the second ground, they increase.

As for the four things,
they are clothing, food and drink, bedding, and medicine.
The other meanings can be understood.
Having engaged in such practices, one receives the wholesome path from the Buddha;
Even if a hundred thousand myriads of kalpas pass, they are not damaged and not lost.
As for not damaged:
Do not allow the precepts to be weak, or it is called not damaged by means of pure matters;
Not practicing at all is called lost.
This bodhisattva thus surpasses the first ground and enters the second ground. As it is said:ğŸ”½Skillfully avoiding the defilements of stinginess and greed, joyfully practicing pure giving;

Pure means only practicing giving with a wholesome mind, not mixed with various afflictions.
Deeply loving means firmly abiding in it, ultimately not abandoning it.
In this ground, the defilements of stinginess and greed, and the defilements of breaking precepts, are left without remainder. Therefore, this ground is called Free from Defilements.

The bodhisattva thus has no stingy or greedy mind, and among the four means of embracing [sentient beings], loving speech is especially beneficial. Among the six perfections, the perfection of morality is especially beneficial.
Benefit means practicing more, with increasing power.
Question:

If in the second ground, the perfection of morality has already gained power, then in this ground, the aspects, arising, power, purity, and distinctions of the perfection of morality should be explained.
Answer:
The perfection of morality is explained in brief with sixty-five aspects;
The arising, power, purity, and distinctions of morality are explained in various treatises.

The perfection of morality is immeasurable and boundless, but it is explained in brief with sixty-five aspects. The arising of morality, the power of morality, the purity of morality, and the distinctions of morality are explained in various treatises before and after.

Because it extinguishes all afflictions, it is called the precept of tranquility.
Because it practices in accordance with the teachings, it is called the precept of following the teachings.
Because of practicing the four means of conversion, it is called the precept of teaching and transforming sentient beings.
Because of not losing one's own Dharma, it is called the precept of protecting the Dharma.
Because of being originally pure, it is called the precept of fulfilling all vows.
Because of dedicating to the unsurpassed path, it is called the precept of reaching the Buddha's Dharma.

These sixty-five parts of the pure precepts of bodhisattvas are then inexhaustible.
The precepts that arise are explained in various places.
In brief, there are eight kinds of precepts that arise:

As for those that arise from the body:
refraining from taking life, refraining from harming sentient beings, refraining from stealing, refraining from sexual misconduct.
As for those that arise from the mouth:

These are called the eight.
These eight kinds of precepts arise from receiving them, and this is the method of receiving them.
If one receives them with the body, speech, or mind, they combine to make twenty-four.
Teaching others to receive them is also twenty-four, rejoicing in receiving them is also twenty-four, and when cultivating and practicing them it is also twenty-fourâ€”together ninety-six.
They are all bound to the desire realm.
They arise from day and night.
Why is this?
The initial mind of receiving has already ceased, and the second mind always arises from day to night.
The merit and virtue are also like this.
Why is this?
The initial mind of giving has already ceased, and after the second mind, when it is used, it should arise. This is called good bodily action.
There are ten wholesome courses of action that are included and not included, bound to the desire realm like this.
Those bound to the form realm are of two kinds:
one arises from the body, and two arise from speech.
Arising from the body means:
It is the sin not included in the ten unwholesome paths of action.
Born from the mouth means:
Free from frivolous speech.
This precept is received by body, mouth, and mind.
Two and three make six, teaching others is also six, rejoicing is also six, and practicing is also six.
Four sixes make twenty-four.
Previously, ninety-six were mentioned, totaling one hundred and twenty.

In this way, precepts born from practice, further, there are precepts born at the time of realizing the path, precepts born at the time of regressing from the path, and precepts born at the time of initial birth.
Due to the vastness of the matter, I will now only briefly explain.
Power of precepts means:
Following the increase of the perfections, the precepts transform and gain power.
Following the stages one attains, the precepts also become firm and powerful.
Purity of precepts means:
Not being destroyed, broken, diminished, and so forth, as explained above.
Furthermore, the characteristics of pure and impure precepts are explained in the seven dharmas of brahma conduct.
As the sutra says:
Using the seven kinds of sexual desire is called impure precepts.
First, although one has cut off sexual desire, one receives a woman's bathing and massage with a defiled mind.
Second, with a defiled mind, one hears the fragrance of a woman, speaks and jokes with her.
Third, with a defiled mind, one looks at each other with eyes.
Fourth, although there are obstacles, one hears the sound of a woman with a defiled mind.
Fifth, although one has previously spoken and laughed with a woman, later, even if separated, one does not let go of the memory.
Sixth, one sets a limit on the time to cut off sexual desire, and then one will do it.
Seventh, one vows to be born in the heavens to enjoy the pleasures of heavenly maidens, and later to be wealthy and happy.
Therefore, cutting off sexual desire is called impure.
Being free from these seven things is called pure precepts.
Distinction in precepts means:
There are two kinds:
First, with outflows; second, without outflows.
There are three kinds:
Bound to the desire realm, bound to the form realm, and unbound.
There are four kinds:
The two kinds that are included in right livelihood are right speech and right action.
The two kinds that are not included in right livelihood are also right speech and right action.
There are five kinds:
The precepts of ordinary people, the precepts of bodhisattvas, the precepts of Å›rÄvakas, the precepts of pratyekabuddhas, and the unsurpassed buddha precepts.
There are six kinds:
The bodily and verbal actions included in right livelihood of the desire realm are one;
Those not included in right livelihood are two;
The bodily and verbal actions bound to the form realm and included in right livelihood are three;
Those not included in right livelihood are four;
The bodily and verbal actions included in the pure right livelihood are five;
Those not included in right livelihood are six.
There are seven kinds:
The seven good courses of action.
There are eight kinds:
As explained above - the four kinds of body and the four kinds of speech.
There are nine kinds:
The seven bound to the desire realm and the two kinds of seven good courses of action.
As explained above.
There are ten kinds:

The three kinds of precepts of the path, the three kinds of counteractive precepts, and the three kinds of mere precepts - these nine kinds of pure precepts and the ten kinds of contaminated precepts,
are distinguished in various ways like this.
Question:
In the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle, bodily actions and verbal actions are called precepts. These two kinds of good actions are called good, and the two kinds of unwholesome actions are called evil.
These good bodily and verbal actions are called precepts. In this treatise, are they considered to be precepts, or are there other precepts?
Answer:
It is not only bodily and verbal actions that are called precepts;
Cultivating, being close to, and delighting in practice are also called precepts.
These three things have the same meaning, namely:
Cultivation, being close to, and delighting in practice.
Question:
If cultivation, being close to, and delighting in practice are called precepts, then all dharmas should be called precepts.
Why is that?
Because they constantly cultivate, become intimate with, and enjoy practicing it.
You should now explain the supreme cultivation of precepts.
Answer:
If there is no self or mine, and one is far removed from all conceptual proliferation,
And nothing is attained at all, this is called the supreme precepts.
If one does not know the true nature of internal and external phenomena, then one gives rise to arrogance and attachment based on the precepts, and thus opens the door to all offenses.

Therefore, if one does not see a self within internal phenomena, does not grasp at a mine among external phenomena, knows that internal and external phenomena are ultimately empty and nothing is attained, and does not grasp at signs and conceptual proliferation even within ultimate emptiness, this is called the supreme precepts.
Why is this?
Within such precepts, there is not even a mistaken mind, let alone bodily or verbal [mistakes].
Therefore, the foremost practitioners of precepts among all Buddhas and Bodhisattvas attain nothing in all dharmas, which is called the supreme precepts.
As the KÄÅ›yapa Chapter SÅ«tra states:
The Buddha told Kasyapa:
Sila is called:

No self, no non-self, no action, no object of action, no agent, no practice, no non-practice, no name, no form, no characteristic, no non-characteristic, not good, not not good, not quiescence, not not quiescence, not grasping, not abandoning.

Kasyapa!

ÅšÄ«la is called:

ÅšÄ«la is called:
Reaching emptiness, arriving at the limit of signlessness, not mixed with the three realms.
The acceptance of non-action, non-arising, and non-birth.
ÅšÄ«la means:

As for discarded rags, they are what people have discarded, which one accepts and then wears.
Accepting means either giving rise to the mind or speaking with the mouth.
Eating in one sitting means not eating again after having first accepted food.
Always sitting means not lying down at night.
Not drinking beverages after meals means not accepting non-time-food such as molasses and other edible things after meals.
Having only three robes means only accepting the three robes and not keeping any other robes.
Woolen robes are made from wool, coarse woolen robes, coarse cloth, felt, and coarse hemp cloth, etc.
Sitting wherever one happens to be means sitting wherever one happens to be, not causing others to rise.
Those who dwell under trees enjoy dwelling under trees and do not enter covered places.
Those who sit in open spaces dwell in the open air.
Those who dwell in charnel houses always abide in charnel houses in accordance with the mind of disgust and detachment.

There are ten benefits to wearing rag robes:

First, one does not associate with householders for the sake of robes, second, one does not show the appearance of begging for robes, third, one does not skillfully speak of the appearance of obtaining robes, fourth, one does not seek in the four directions for the sake of robes, fifth, if one does not obtain robes one is not worried, sixth, if one obtains them one is not delighted, seventh, cheap goods are easy to obtain and there are no problems, eighth, this is in accordance with the practice of first accepting the four foundations of mindfulness, ninth, one enters the ranks of those who wear coarse robes, and tenth, one is not coveted by others.
There are also ten benefits to eating in one sitting:

First, no fatigue from seeking a second meal; second, lightness in what is received; third, no fatigue in using it; fourth, no fatigue before eating; fifth, entering the subtle practice of eating; sixth, eating after digestion; seventh, few hindrances and afflictions; eighth, few illnesses; ninth, the body is light and convenient; tenth, the body is blissful.
Constantly sitting also has ten benefits:

After eating, not accepting food outside of the proper time also has ten benefits:

The three robes also have ten benefits:

Accepting woolen robes also has ten benefits:

There are also ten benefits to sitting wherever one spreads one's seat:
